intro: Blepharipappus laevis, commonly known as the silky pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive bract structures. The plant features narrow, linear leaves and produces small, white to yellowish flowers in late summer. Its most notable botanical feature is the silky, hair-like pappus that surrounds its seeds, aiding in wind dispersal. It thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils.
